Retrospectively,  Batman: Arkham Asylum  is the high point of Rocksteady Studios'  Batman  trilogy. It's a tight, focused experience with a deft tonal awareness, shaping a dark, grotesque setting for a plot that hits all the 'edgy  Batman  story' notes, relying on spectacle - supplemented by some pretty top-tier action and stealth gameplay - to see it through.  Similarly to the way  Asylum  itself is the pinnacle of the  Arkham  series,  Arkham Asylum 's third-person melee combat is quite easily the best to be found within this genre. It's fluid and functional, with solid ability variation supplemented by superb animation and sound design shaping an experience that is - at its core - quintessential to the cheesy, ridiculously one-sided combat of superhero comic books. Despite the borderline omnipotence of Batman's combat ability, the fights never became overly unchallenging, as the game introduces new enemy abilities frequently enough to keep you juggling knives, stun batons and giant experimental abominations. Regarding stealth gameplay,  Arkham Asylum  utilises mechanics that necessitate a predatory approach - if you're spotted by armed enemies, you'll be dead in seconds. Creeping around in the shadows and picking off burly, shirtless men until they start to panic is great fun, but it tends to be even more one-sided than the combat. It's almost as though there's too much freedom to just hang out on a rooftop with the x-ray vision constantly turned on until a specific enemy moves far enough away from the group for you to drop down and take him out, and then rinse and repeat. The endless functions of the x-ray vision makes it almost irresponsible not to keep the thing turned on, despite the fact that it replaces pretty much all textures with various shades of dark blue. The somewhat 'Mary Sue' nature of most superheroes is probably the cause of troubles like this - people would complain if Batman didn't have tons of ultra-powerful gadgets like this. Regardless, it doesn't totally ruin the game's balance, it just tends to make a lot of encounters a touch too easy.   Arkham Asylum  is pretty aesthetically brilliant. Voice performances by long-time Batman and Joker voice actors Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill adds an air of authenticity to the dialogue, as does top-tier animation and some genuinely creepy underground sequences. While the plot is more of the same stuff you'll find in a lot of  Batman  comics ( Arkham Asylum  is primarily based on Grant Morrison's 1989 comic  Arkham Asylum: A Serious House on Serious Earth ), it's still good stuff. Not because of the storyline itself, which is samey and tedious, but because of the amount of work put into the various villainous characters, particularly the Scarecrow, whose subplot features some pretty interesting surprises along the way. It's in the depictions of established characters that the story shines, coming close to the 'definitive versions' that the endless superhero film reboots seem to be going for.  Arkham Asylum  really ramps it up towards the ending with some fancy setpieces that are actually very enjoyable. In general, the game shines as a rare example of a popular IP being adapted into a video game that actually manages to gel the elements of the  Batman​  franchise with what makes video games inherently fun.

As much as I love playing creative indie games, it is really refreshing to play a game with a huge budget where they worked closely with Nvidia to optimize the graphics and make a 3D Vision ready game. What I mean by all of this is: Batman: Arkham Asylum looks gorgeous! There were even a few scenes that had a lot of PhysX effects going on that my GTX 670 struggled with. I wouldn't have guessed that it came out in 2009. One of my biggest pet peeves is when games that look great have cutscenes that have been rendered in 720p (I'm looking at you, Mass Effect series) but the only difference I could see in Asylum was that the cutscenes were not in 3D.  I'm not a huge Batman fan, so I don't know who most of the villains are; I only learned about Two Face when I watched The Dark Knight. Arkham Asylum does a very good job of introducing the characters and giving their backgrounds. They even have a little bio section for each major character with both in-universe and real life facts about them. I could tell that most of the character designs were new takes on those characters, and I definitely think that they were done well. I found it a little odd that almost every single person in the game was ripped, but this is Batman after all.  Mark Hamill did a phenomenal job voicing the Joker. He was easily the most interesting character tho listen to, and I intentionally died a couple of times so I could listen to him taunt me.  Each main villain had a couple of levels devoted to them. My personal favorite were the Scarecrow levels because I got to relive some of the defining moments in Batman's life. By that I mean I got to see his parents die.  The gameplay is pretty basic: left-click to hit people, and right-click to counter when they try to hit you. Some enemy types switch this up a little by making you stun them first or dodging behind them before you can hit them, but ultimately it only adds one extra button that you have to hit before taking them down.  My favorite parts of the game were the rooms where there were a bunch of armed thugs in a large area, and I had to figure out how to take them down without being seen. It reminded me of the scenes in Batman Begins down by the docks where Batman did just that. Unfortunately I wasn't quite as good at it as the real Batman.  The detective 'puzzles' were fairly interesting, but usually very straightforward. I felt like I was doing less detective work and more just following a trail that the developers would only let me see if I turned on the special goggles.  My least favorite parts by far were the boss battles. They were clearly constructed exactly the same way that boss battles were made back in the 90's. I was usually stuck on a platform below the much larger boss, performing the same actions multiple times while looking for patterns in their attacks so I knew when they were vulnerable.  It took me a little over 10 hours to complete the story. It seemed like I wasn't missing much by not exploring heavily; the main missions took me all over the island. It would have been nice to have gotten more of the audio logs, which were pretty amusing, and I only found a fraction of the Riddler trophies. I'm definitely not a completionist.  Overall I enjoyed the game a lot, and I would recommend that anyone who thinks Batman is the coolest play it. It's currently $20, which is a pretty reasonable price.

Previous Superhero games before this were pretty bad (Spider-Man 2 is an exception) the stories were laughable and they often had god-awful controls and poor gameplay. Then in 2009 Batman: Arkham Asylum came out, developed by Rocksteady Studios in London as their second game. This game had a moderate amount of hype at the time (everyone was scarred this would be a failure) however upon release it gained mass appeal. Graphically the game looks great, has some awesome environments and character models. The storyline is great too (written by Paul Dini, who also the Batman: Animated Series) and features a good roster of Batman Villians, and manages to balance the story and characters pretty well. The gameplay is amazing, it features an easy to learn but difficult to master hand to hand combat system mixed with Batman gadgets, and to complement the gameplay the control scheme is great (recommend a gamepad). The game also has stealth sections which are enjoyable however they are often repetitive and players often use the same tactics over and over (the AI in the late game does try to mix things up later), there is also a detective mode where you need to scan various crime scenes which is sadly the weakest part of the gameplay as all you do is scan an item and follow a breadcrumb trail to the next area (also the detective mode feature can be used in combat or in the stealth sections however this makes those sections a cake walk). Finally if you like collectables this game has a crap ton of them, they litter the entire map and tie into the unlock system Batman has to unlock gadgets/abilities, in the post-game you can hover them up.  Pros: - Great Batman game! - Great graphics, and good looking environments and characters. - Great controls (recommend a gamepad). - Gameplay is awesome and doesn't bore the player (some sections however are a bit tedious). - Great story and dialogue. - Scarecrow sections are fantastic.  Cons: - Some bugs. - DLC is missable just some challenge maps that can tax your abilities in combat/ Stealth arenas. - Stealth sections are a bit on the easy side/ not challenging once you have beaten the first couple until later in the game. - Some tedious bits in the game, also a fair amount of backtracking is involved. - So many collectables to find (they do tie into the Batman lore though).  9/10  TL:DR: It's a great Batman game, really good single player campaign. Perfect balance of gameplay/graphics. And it has some great scriptwriting.

Batman: Arkham Asylum is a visually pleasing game with the atmosphere and soundtrack dripping with tension and adventure. The land and buildings are brooding and never seem repetitive. Each building is unique and I enjoyed exploring each and every one of them.   Batman’s “Detective Mode” was fun to play with but sadly, I found myself in Detective Mode more than 80% of the game in order to detect crates and destructible walls trying to collect all 240 Riddler items. While in Detective Mode you lose out on the beauty and detail of the land and interiors. Which is a shame because there is so much packed into this game. Each area has something a little unique. It could be an odd plaque on a table, Calendar Man’s cell covered in dates, Harley Quinn’s room with Joker pictures everywhere, and other random things all tied to Batman’s lore and rouges gallery.  The fighting in Batman is amazing to watch. When I first started I was button mashing. As I progressed I learned that everything must be timed. Once I realized this and started learning all of the combos and counters, fighting became a joy. Each boss fight is different and I died many times each time until I figured out how to actually beat each one.  Last, but not least, the story is engaging and showcases Joker as the “Mega-Super-Planner”. The opening scene is great comedy. By the time the game starts, you really like the Joker. I laughed often listening to Joker as he berates you as you progress through the game. The interview tapes you find scattered across Arkham Island really add to the game and story. You learn a lot about all of the different villain’s backgrounds and motivations. When all is done and the night is won, you'll be left wondering why anyone would ever live in Gotham.  This game is great fun to play and I enjoyed every minute of it. Even the frustrating ones.

Here is my review for Batman: Arkham Asylum GOTY Edition  Intro: The story places after Batman has finally captured Joker and is transporting him to Arkham Asylum. He senses something bigger is happening, but isn't sure what it is. After entering Arkham Asylum, Batman becomes just another inmate and must battle his enemies and restore order the Asylum.  Gameplay / Sound: Batman AA plays like a super advanced version of crackdown. Don't know crackdown? Well its a action adventure game where you use buttons to chain together attacks and combine with Batman's arsenal. It involves kicks, batarangs, batman's cape, explosive gel and many other items. While in combat you can chain these weapons along with dodge and counter button to quickly wipe out the enemy. The second part is part stealth action game, where you can take down enemies without alerting anyone, in classic Batman fashion. There is great satisifaction from taking on 6-10 enemies and just picking them all off, one by one. The only issue I have with this is that you have to watch 'slow mo' kills on the last enemy. Granted you can skip it, it almost doesnt feel really necessary to also cut to that. All the inmates are like mini hulks and just look like the can bash your skull in, luckily Batman is a master of combat. After about the first couple of hours the combat begins to grow stale and repetitive. If you complete 100 % everything like I do, than it almost becomes a grind. Other than that a normal playthrough will be enough for most players. The sound effects whether you are solving riddler challenges or destroying Joker's toy teeth, each sound is unique that you'll always remember what each sound indicates. The voices of fan favorites shows up in Batman AA and makes the game very nostalgic.  Story : The story of Arkham Asylum revolves around Batman trying to escape from AA and stop the Joker from unleashing a weapon upon Gotham. The story is fleshed out between common knowledge, background audio tapes dubbed 'patient reports' and through dialogue. In terms of complete story Batman AA has it all. A clear Beginning, Middle and End. You never are lost and are always free to continue the main story whenever. This means going on 'side quests' to collect all the goodies hidden in the asylum. The story mainly focuses on Joker and Batman, but many other villains show up to help move the plot along. The story is almost purely confinded to the island, whether it is above or below, you grow to love the asylum, no matter how many enemies reside within its walls.  Replayability: Batman AA has tons of replayability for players who are looking to collect all the achievements, records, and solve the riddlers questions. Outside of all those things, there isn't any main story to complete after you run through it. Extra modes like the fighting, stealth and reward challenges will keep you busy, but after that the replay value decreases. Batman AA is meant for a story playthrough and includes all these extras to keep you interested. Most people will just complete the story and will be satisfied with their time on Arkham Asylum.   Controls: The controls are fluid and really smooth. Rocksteady worked hard on this and makes it very easy for anyone to pick and a play. There is no big learning curve which makes this a very attractive game to new users and veteran players.  Conclusion: If you are looking into buying Arkham Asylum or a Batman fan, this is the game for you. The original and still the best in the series.  It's more focused environment leads to a more tightly crafted game that just begs to be explored. While the later games in the series offer a more open ended approach with arguably more things to see and do, in practice they seem to offer little more than filler between heavily scripted events. While collectibles, secrets and side missions often feel like chores in the later games, they feel like meaningful reasons to fully explore the asylum with appropriate rewards on offer. Each area is filled with unique assets and small, rememberable details. The riddlers side missions task you with photographing scenes that are unique to various characters from the Dark Knight universe which helps to direct the player toward these specially crafted, and unique in-game assets.  The combat system, while arguably too simplistic, is a delight to control as you see Batman stringing insane combo's together effortlessly disarming, and countering incoming attacks. Every kick, punch, grapple and counter is animated well making fights seem appropriately realistic and violent. The combat is assisted by some excellent audio leading to some satisfying crunches, cracks, and smacks as bones break and fists collide with faces.  The metroid-vania aspects of the game are implemented well, with each upgrade offering the oppertunity to revisit locations throughout the game.  The story is well told and the voice acting is excellent throughout, although I felt the final parts of the story were anticlimactic with the final boss fight in particular being tedius and frankly, rather silly. Seeing the Joker turn into a roid-raged meathead seemed rather out of character, and a little far-fetched - even for a comic book super villain.  On a technical level, the game still looks great to this day and runs exceptionally well. A mid-range pc should be able to run this game on maximum settings with a solid 60fps.  All-in-all it's a ground breaking game and in my opinion one of the best games of it's generation. A true masterpiece.

Batman: Arkham Asylum is a 2009 action-adventure video game based on the DC Comics superhero Batman. It was developed by Rocksteady Studios and published by Eidos Interactive in conjunction with Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment for the PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360 video game consoles, and Microsoft Windows. It was released worldwide for consoles, beginning in North America on August 25, 2009, with a Microsoft Windows version following on September 15.  Written by veteran Batman writer Paul Dini, Arkham Asylum is based on the long-running comic book mythos. In the game's main storyline, Batman's archenemy, the Joker, instigates an elaborate plot to seize control of Arkham Asylum and trap Batman inside with many of his incarcerated foes. With Joker threatening to detonate hidden bombs around fictional Gotham City, Batman is forced to fight his way through the asylum's inmates and put an end to the Joker's plans. Most of the game's leading characters are voiced by actors who have appeared in other media based on the DC Animated Universe; Kevin Conroy, Mark Hamill, and Arleen Sorkin reprised their roles as Batman, the Joker, and his sidekick Harley Quinn respectively. The game is presented from the third-person perspective with a primary focus on Batman's combat and stealth abilities, detective skills, and gadgets that can be used in combat and exploration.  The game received critical acclaim—particularly for its narrative—and won several awards, including Best Action Adventure game, Best Game, and Game of the Year from different media outlets. It held the Guinness World Record for 'Most Critically Acclaimed Superhero Game Ever'. A Game of the Year edition was released on March 26, 2010, and an OS X version was released in November 2011. Arkham Asylum '​s success launched a series of Batman: Arkham sequels, beginning in October 2011 with Batman: Arkham City.

Batman Simulator 2009. Arkham Asylum is one damn good action game, surprising for a western-developed title, and one damn good stealth game, surprising for a modern video game (ded genre etc). The combat is simple but also somewhat complex, with quite a few gadgets and moves, and a LOT of ways to take down enemies. The stealth and combat in Asylum can be mixed together at will, (except when fighting armed enemies, in which case it is too dangerous to fight them openly) providing a lot of different gameplay possibilities for the player. While learning the advanced uses of moves and gadgets is not necessary for the player to truly succeed in the normal game, the challenge mode is where the game's combat shines. On top of the base game and the challenges, which are all reasonably difficult, the game also comes with a harder difficulty mode that will really wreck your ♥♥♥♥. It's a little bit broken because the game's combat is very reliant on the appearence of shining attack indicators over enemies before they strike, which are gone when playing the hardest difficulty, but overall it remains one of the hardest action games I've played in the last few years. The stealth is also wonderful. It's very fast, and requires proper use of your gadgets and tools. There's never a moment in Arkahm Asylum's stealth where you're doing nothing or waiting for something to happen. It also has a very interesting system of fear tactics, where you can get various effects out of enemies with fear. Arkham Asylum features my favourite depiction of Batman and Gotham City, it being in my opinion a perfect blend of the style of the animated series and the more realistic versions of the live-action films. The art style (and graphics) is fantastic, and that's without even mentioning the amazing Scarecrow segments scattered throughout the game. The biggest problem with this game is probably the integration with Games For Windows Live, even on Steam. But if that doesn't bother you too much, you should definately give this game a try. You won't regret it.

This game has got to be one of the more overrated titles in recent memory, even taking into account historical context. Overall it's just boring with plenty of style but little substance. Arkham Asylum is an incredible Batman experience as it succeeds it what a Batman game should be like: allow you to be Batman. Its gameplay, story and design all make you feel like the Caped Crusader and is one of, if not the best licensed title we've ever gotten.  Arkham Asylum's story pits the Dark Knight against a plethora of classic villains from the Batman's rogues gallery who are all pawns in the Joker's master plan. Honestly, the story on its own and Rocksteady's take on the Batman mythos are worth so much just on its own. The way they cleverly write the whole rogues gallery essentially into this game, either through story or easter eggs, is genious at least. It also happens to be one of the best Joker stories in recent memory.  Just story alone really makes this game, but the fact is that the gameplay is also insanely good. And I'm not just saying that because Batman, but because all the game mechanics and level design are excellent in their own right! The combat system this game crafted has been copied by so many games already. The simple freeflow combat mechanic where you can counter enemies' attacks and keep your chain going is just simplicity at its best. The stealth portions of the game are also very good with level design giving a hand in those sections.   All the gadgets available to Batman are useful and do very different things, not only in combat and stealth, but also in puzzle-solving, collectible hunting and platforming. The Metroidvania style of gameplay and Bioshock type ambience also really make the game's atmosphere really shine and make for a dark and gritty Batman story. They also explore and enliven the Asylum which is usually not shown too much. The whole concept of spending the entire game on the Asylum with all your superpowered nemeses, during one night is genious and they have managed to pull it off perfectly.  Even if you're not a Batman fan, you'll become one after playing this game. Gameplay and story are all excellently crafted and add to this essential Batman experience. This game is most definitely worth your time.  A must-buy!

Quick Breakdown:  A strong superhero game that combines elements of action and stealth, taking place in a dark and gritty Arkham Asylum. Strong voice acting and dialogue, along with a fun story help propel the game even further along. It properly delivers a thrilling experience playing as the dark knight.  Length:  12 hours (Main game)  Score:  8/10   Full Review:  The Dark Knight has long been a beloved character for many, and I don’t think I’m alone in wanting to play as the caped crusader. Thankfully, Arkham Asylum delivers this experience in spades.  The setting for this experience is Gotham city’s Arkham Asylum, home for the criminally insane. In proper Batman fashion it’s dark and gritty, taking place in the night and filled with shadows. Those kept locked away in the asylum have broken free, and under the Joker’s leadership, are now in control of their prison. Retaking the asylum and defeating the Joker and the other inmates is, as you’ve likely guessed, your mission in the game.  The game’s story is fun, and is your typical sort of Batman plotline. It’s not an all-time great Batman story, but it will keep you entertained throughout the course of the game (though the ending is rather weak and stupid). The greater highlight is the voice acting and dialogue featured in the game. Many voice actors from the 1990’s animated series lend their talents to the game, including Kevin Conroy as Batman, and Mark Hamill as the Joker. Hamill steals the show, showing once again why he is so superb at voicing the Joker. He snarls, mocks, and cackles as if he were the madman himself, and the Joker’s comments and mockery as you fight to retake the asylum are highly entertaining.   Though Hamill’s efforts as the Joker overshadow the rest of the cast, it should be noted that many other characters are well voiced, and their dialogue as well is entertaining as you play through the game. This from both the big names in Bats’ rogue gallery, such as the Riddler’s mocking condescension as you solve his challenges (more on those in a bit), and the Scarecrow taunting you as you overcome the fear induced from his toxin; as well as the over-confident boasting of the Joker’s grunts, and especially as their chatter turns to nervousness and then fear as you pick of their comrades.  Of course, when discussing a game one must talk about the most important part of the medium: the gameplay itself. Thankfully the game does not slouch here either, successfully giving you the experience of being Batman (as much as a game can anyway). The gameplay includes both elements of stealth and action, each being an entertaining experience.  During the stealth portions, you must tactically pick off your enemies one by one, avoiding detection, lest they fill you with lead. To do so you must creep in the shadows, and crawl through air ducts, hide beneath floor tiles, and swing from gargoyles from high above. You have various ways to silently dispense of your enemies, such as dropping down on them from above, stringing them up from a gargoyle, or a discrete melee attack from behind. To aid you in your quiet takedown of enemies you can use detective mode, which gives you a greater view of the land, allowing you to look through walls, floors, and ceilings to see where enemies are located. Additionally, detective mode will tell you how many enemies are in the area, how many are armed, and how many are unarmed, as well as which are which.  The action sequences feature more direct combat, as you utilize feet and fists in a direct assault against your enemies. This is one of the strongest points of the game; it’s simple but elegant combat system. You use one button to attack, and another to counterattack when a few blue lines flash about an enemy combatants head. Strikes must be properly timed, so as to earn combos, which not only grant you more experience towards earning upgrades, but also do more damage, ending a fight more quickly and efficiently. During fights you are not left to use only your limbs as weapons, as you are equipped with your trusty batarangs to stun enemies, as well as being able to stun foes with a strike from your cape.  As you level up you can purchase upgrades that increase your fighting abilities, the gear you use, and your health.  Sometimes throughout the game you will be transported to a bizarre place, where you must defeat the Scarecrow. During these segments you must hide from Scarecrows gaze, and make your way to the top of the area, which have some light platforming elements. Later Scarecrow stages will also involve skeleton enemies that you must fight off, while still evading Scarecrow’s gaze. These segments are a lot of fun, and are a highly memorable part of the game.  Occasionally throughout the game you will face off against one of the many villains from Gotham. Sadly, these battles are rather lackluster, and are one of the glaring weaknesses of the game. While I wouldn’t go as far as to call them bad, I must say that they are rather mediocre, and don’t shine as brightly as the rest of the game.  In addition to the main content of the game, there are also Riddler challenges, which task you to find hidden trophies and symbols hidden throughout the world map. While I didn’t find them particularly compelling, they do provide a distraction from the main game in case you need. As for myself, I merely collected the ones I managed to find as I went through the game, and didn’t bother to seek out any additional ones.  The bonus content for the game features additional challenge missions for you to partake in. There are two types of challenge levels, the first is a combat oriented mission, where you must fight through successive waves of enemies, aiming for the highest score you can. The other is a stealth mission, where you are tasked to take out your enemies as quickly as you can, and are rewarded for taking them out in certain ways. All said, the bonus content included isn’t very interesting, and I didn’t spend any more time on it than it took to get a feel for what it is.  As for the bonus content is included as part of the GOTY edition (originally released as DLC), there are 4 bonus challenges to play through. They are in much the same vein as the regular bonus content, being a mix of combat and stealth levels. Likewise with the other bonus content, they too are lackluster and not particularly entertaining.  In addition to my criticisms already mentioned, I feel must mention that the load times for the game are a bit long, especially when dying and waiting for the game to reload. Additionally, it’s a tad ambiguous at times when they game is at a checkpoint that will save your progress at a point you can resume from when you reload the next time you boot up the game. There were a few occasions where I thought I had reached a checkpoint, only to have to redo a small portion of the game the next time I resumed play. Given that there is no option to manually save the game this is a bit more troubling than it should be. Thankfully this isn’t too major of an issue, but it is still annoying and unnecessary.  At the end of the day though, this is still a strong game, and certainly one of the best superhero games out there, delivering the sort of experience one deserves from a Batman game; you get to sneak around and beat up criminals as you play as the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Batman. What more could you want?

Who is this Game For? ================== Batman: Arkham Asylum is packed with fan service as Batman faces off against more than just one big name in the franchise. Sure, you'll encounter The Joker and Harley Quinn, but you're also going to run into the likes of Bane, Killer Croc, Poison Ivy, Scarecrow and Zsasz. A multitude of other villains are referenced in various ways, even though they don't actually appear in person. Either way, for those who are hardcore fans of the franchise, it's a nice touch.  Is it good? ================= Making your way through the story, three types of game play quickly become apparent: combat, stealth and exploration. In short, pretty much all the fighting is handled with two buttons and timing. Get the timing down, and you'll be whipping out amazing combos with a simple tap-tap-tap. The stealth game play is referred to as 'predator mode' by the developers since it is most directly inspired by the classic Batman of the comics. Here, the focus is on creating fear and eliminating enemies when they are vulnerable. Exploration is more or less standard plat forming, but combined with Batman's cool gadgets.  Audio is a strong point for Batman: Arkham Asylum, be it music, sound effects or voice acting. Mark Hamill reprises his role as The Joker, while Kevin Conroy stars as Batman and Arleen Sorkin voices Harley Quinn. It all makes for good visuals, even if things do look a bit plastic at times. PhysX support appears to be PC-only, which means you’ll only find volumetric fog, detailed cloth animation or random destructible items such as paper and tiles here on the PC version.  Does it have any problems? ======================== Where Batman: Arkham Asylum stumbles is in the boss fights. Some, such as the battle against Poison Ivy, are challenging in an old-school, learn the pattern way. Others, such as the (multiple) fights against the Scarecrow, are brilliantly executed. But most are repetitive fights against low level enemies and are more an exercise in button-mashing than any sort of challenge.  Final Thoughts! ==================== In addition to the main game, Batman: Arkham Asylum also features a wealth of unlockable information in the form of characters bios, audio interviews with key inmates, beautifully rendered character trophies and the aforementioned challenge maps. Challenge maps are split into combat and predator style, with the goal of the combat maps being a high score and the goal of the predator maps being elimination of the enemies as quickly as possible. There have been many different Batman games over the years, but none quite so polished as this one. Batman: Arkham Asylum combines the best elements of the classic Batman mythos with the modern-day interpretation of the hero. The end result is a game that outshines its flaws and is quite simply a blast to play.  --------------------------------

The best Batman Game, and in my opinion the best use of a licensed character closely followed by this titles sequel 'Arkham City'. Arkham Asylum puts you in the shoes of the World’s Greatest Detective in transit to Arkham Asylum directly following catching the Joker in Gotham. In true Joker fashion though, this simple booking procedure goes wrong, and Joker takes over the Asylum. Now you as Batman has to figure out what the Clown Prince of Crime is up too. Along the way you see and battle the A-Team of batman Villains who happen to be locked up in the Asylum.   Visually Arkahm Aslyum still holds its weight and looks great. The art direction in this game does an incredible job in complementing the emotions and feelings the writers are trying to convey. From the cramped insides of the Asylum to incredible vistas from Arkham Island looking out at Gotham. I also enjoyed that despite the massive success of 'Nolan’s Batman' this game is throwing you into the Batman from the Comics or Cartoon that I grew up with.   In keeping with Nostalgia, Rocksteady got the two greatest voice actors to reprise their roles as Batman and Joker. Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill respectively. These voices are the ones that most of here when we read the comics and both Actors do a phenomenal job, coupled with great writing from Rocksteady.   For anyone is worried that because the story and visual presentation are so superb that the gameplay must be shallow, which happens often. I can ease your mind, Arkham Aslyum's gameplay is tight responsive and truly makes you feel like the Caped Crusader. Combat when out in the open completed with 'free-flow' combat, which when first introduced seems like single button directional combat. But they do a great job of building on it as the game goes on adding in gadgets, parries, stuns, and diverse unit types.   Along with great combat, Arkham Island is full of Exploration and puzzles to solve. Throughout the game you will be taunted by The Riddler to solve his puzzles, which range from grabbing statues to finding hidden Easter Eggs spread out around the world with hints given in Riddle-Form, and using your Detective Mode vision to find hidden 'Question Marks'. Detective mode is a vision where you can see enemies through walls in skeletal form and other important objects will be highlighted (Be warned you will spend a good amount of time in this vision a lot more than you would think)   I could go on and on but do not want to give any Spoilers because that where Arkham shines is in delivering an incredibly well-paced and well written Batman story worthy of the Title. If you want to not only feel like Batman but be put into a great Batman Story this game is a must play  5/5 - please read more of my reviews and add me

The joker is taking over the asylum, and you are trapped inside.  I had no idea of this game when I tried it the first time. I have never been a fan of DC either. But man, this is a great game, no matter if you like the comic or not.  Some people say, and I tend to agree partially, that this is still the best game in the batman series. The latter two games in the series are more open world, which some might prefer. But I found the story and the game play a little more contained (in a good sense) and with better pacing. It feels slightly like the open-world was added to the latter games just because that is popular, while in fact the games don't really need it. They are still great games, but it is not the open-world aspect that makes the games great.  The game is beautiful (even though it does not demand the best PC), there is so much to do, and all aspects of the game are interesting and well made. The combat is incredibly smooth and satiesfying, even though on paper it looks rather simple. You really feel strong and powerful being batman. I find it a perfect combination of stealth and fighting. But batman is also a great detective, and the gadgets are really inovative and fun to use. There are quite a few ways to 'travel' around, and the games has tons of extras to find, which might make you want to come back again. There are also boss-fights, and even though I don't like boss fights normally, these are fun, and sometimes quite interesting and innovative. The voice acting is very very good (the joker is Mark Hamill for example) The whole lore and universe is interesting and deep. I learned a lot about the batman universe playing this game, and I really felt every antagonist had an interesting story and depth. The game is dark in the right way. It does not feel silly at all. It really feels like the game was made by people who love and respect this comic. It is a game about batman, not just a way to cash in on a great icon. This game delivers well even if you are a fan or not.  I think it runs great with mouse and keyboard, and this time I did not try it with a controller, but I can't imagine that being a better option anyway.

I honestly have to say this is one of the best licensed games out there. Scratch that, one of the best action adventure games out there.  The reason why this game is so great is that it has strong gameplay, great visuals and an awesome soundtrack and it doesn't rely on being a Batman game to fool people into buying it. Don't get me wrong though, this is a Batman game, from beginning to end. Rocksteady have crafted one of the most unique and well designed gameplay experiences of the action adventure genre that suits the Dark Knight perfectly. This is particularly impressive considering most licensed games do it the other way around: trying to fit the characters into an already existing gameplay style. This game does exactly the opposite and that's what makes it so incredible.  Speaking of the gamplay style, it is a healthy mix of action combat bits, stealth sections, environmental exploration and even some minimal platforming and detective bits. All of these feel distinctly Batman-y in every way though so don't be fooled into thinking this is just another generic action adventure title.  The combat sections in Arkham Asylum do a great job of making you feel like the Dark Knight. They are very unique as they focus on timing your strikes and flowing smoothly into each next move without ever braking your combo rather than the standard button mashing and long button sequence memorization in most games. In fact the actual button sequences you need to remember are very minimal. Most of the game you will spend only using two buttons really: attacking and countering. The attack button does what you can imagine but the counter is a bit more interesting. It allows you to automatically counter incoming attacks indicated by the little Spiderman-esque lightning bolts that appear on top of enemies' heads when they are about to attack. This may seem like a very simple system, and for the most part it is, but even though the system is easy to get into, it is hard to master as it requires a lot of timing to execute properly. It is truly brilliant and it's no wonder it's becoming the system most game devs have started using. It just makes you feel like a badass.  The stealth is equally as interesting and fun although it is more standard stuff. The focus here is using your environment to your advantage to take out threats without being seen. To do this you get a wide variety of options for silent take downs each as satisfying as the next. The only thing I need to say here is that these sections don't feel slapped on like they do in most other action games. They really fit and are great fun.  The environmental exploration is in the form of Riddler trophies and riddles. Dotted around the island there are many question mark trophies placed by the Riddler. Sometimes to get them you just need to find them but sometimes they require a certain gadget or upgrade to be obtained. The riddles themselves are about scanning a certain landmark or object that answers the riddle for the said area. Don't worry though, it's never anything too obscure like in the old point and click days. No leaves in the corner of the Arkham mansion need to be scanned. These trophies are very rewarding to collect both in a literal sense and a personal accomplishment sense.  The story and visuals are great and fit into the Batman mythos amazingly. I won't spoil much but it's great fun for fans of the Dark Knight and even those who don't care about Batman might enjoy it. It's very well written and voice acted.  The only con I see is that the game is sometimes easy to get lost in due to the dark bleak environments. You do have a map though for that but it is still a minor annoyance. The bosses are also pretty weak as you only get one type of them for most of the game. I feel like they could of been so much more.  That said, the cons are very small and this game is an absolute diamond for any Batman fans and fans of good games in general. Highly recommended to everyone. 9/10.

Originally posted Sept 15 2009  gameaday-ish.blogspot.com   ...  Arkham is not tied to any specific property other than the characters than have populated the Batman universe for over 50 years. Seeking inspiration in all of the media that has come before, the game references the Christian Bale movies, the Tim Burton movies, all of the animated series and the comics themselves, weaving these details into a claustrophobic, atmospheric story.  Penned by animated series and comic creator Paul Dini, the pitfall found in Wolverine is avoided by casting voices from the animated series, namely Kevin Conroy as Batman and Mark Hamill as the Joker. As fully committed to the performances as Jackman, they create familiarity to fans of character without jeopardizing the verisimilitude of the presentation. Had Arkham been tied to Dark Knight, it may well suffer from some of the issues facing Wolverine.  The seemingly ubiquitous Unreal 3 engine makes a spectacular appearance, rendering large colorful worlds that appear open but are quite limited in scope. Once again, the decision to set AA on an island and solely within the facility grounds serves the game well, motivating the linear aspect of play.   I found it amusing that expositional scenes revealed through off camera radio transmissions are in full force in the game, as apparently that is a feature built into the engine. The animations for these sequences are identical to the ones uses in Gears.  What I found most striking in the difference between these very similar games was the presentation of the main character and their interaction with the environment through gameplay. Batman uses his familiar bag of tricks from his utility belt, resulting in a cavalcade of gadgets and upgrades. Platforming is restricted to using a grapple gun and a glide ability, referencing both the movies and the animated shows. Puzzles are integrated into a detective mode as Challenges left by the Riddler.   Combat is an integral part of the game and Batman’s combat is a far more nuanced and cerebral experience, playing much like a real-time Bruce Lee movie. Counters are used to intercept attacks, allowing the player to chain together attacks and build up multipliers, which unleash finishing moves. Strategy must be employed and it is a far more satisfying experience.  Against the odds, junior developer Rocksteady created a tour-du-force experience in AA, while Raven managed what appeared to be impossible prior to AA’s release: create a good comic book game. Wolverine is a very entertaining game but it pales in comparison to the masterwork that is Arkham Asylum.

I really love everything about this game. The story is fun and interesting, and it actually requires skill, timing, and strategy to complete the stealth missions. The challenges keep me entertained even after I have finished the story, and the infinite challenges could be their own game in and of themselves. I have almost all those dang Riddler Trophies, some of which are really hard to find, and take some real patience to seek out. I have only completed the game in Easy mode, so I hope to play through it a couple more times in Normal and Hard mode.  PROS: -GREAT story and plot! -Voice acting is superb! I really love Mark Hamil's Joker, and it really makes this feel like a Batman game! -Music is AMAZING! It really adds tension and helps the situations feel more real. This is most apparent, to me, during the killer croc fight. -The SOUNDS in ths game are great! I can feel it in my gut every time I dislocate someone's elbow or snap their leg, and all the gadgets have great sound effects as well! -Great combat OVERALL. There are a few minor issues, but I can work around them. Combat really does take skill in this game. You have to have good timing and tactics. -Stealth mechanics are fun. I love being able to clear out a room of baddies without a single one seeing me, and there's always more than one way to complete a stealth mission. -Gadgets are fun to play around with. Batman has everything from remote control batarangs to explosive gel. The gadgets are all fun in their own way, and are really essential to completing stealth missions. -Movement is pretty good. I love the feel of gliding, and for some reason it's fun just running around and jumping over stuff. -I can easily plug in a controller and start playing without havingto adjust any settings (but I prefer keyboard controls). With a keyboard combat is much faster, and I can look around alot faster.  CONS: -BIGGEST PROBLEM WITH THE GAME: Once you complete the story, there are no more goons to fight in the asylum. It makes sense in context with the story, but I would really like to be able to explore the Asylum AND fight some baddies. After the story is over, it becomes really boring to wander around looking for trophies. -While I may enjoy the combat overall, there are a few frustrations. Sometimes my counters seem to lag, or if the game goes into slow motion, sometimes I can never counter at all. Other than that combat is great! -Movement is fine, however there is very little precision. This is really obvious when you are trying to line up riddler trophy spray paint, which you have to look at from a specific place and at a specific angle. It is also apparent when you are trying to sneak around. Often it's hard for me to be sneaky when I keep bumbling around. I can work around this, however, so it's a minor complaint. -I have an XBox controller I plug in to let people who are not accostumed to keyboard control play. However, whenever I try playing with a controller, I find the controls clunky and very slow. It is much easier to play with a keyboard and mouse. This is another very minor complaint because I never use the controller if I can help it.  Overall I give this a 9/10. There are a few minor issues, but the good things far outweigh the bad!

If you love Batman, get it. -You finally get to be the Bat and do the stuff he does best, solving crime and serving justice (YAY!) 2.) The combat mechanics of the game are simple but challenging. -The combat mechanincs of the are really simple but challenging enough to have you thinking your next attack. Plus the combat is so fluid, you'll enjoy playing as much as watching the fight play out. 3.) The riddles are challenging and really satisfying to do. -I finished all the riddles and yeah, I feel pretty proud of myself for finishing all the riddles and yes, you do feel like the Bat when solving the riddles. Think like your enemy and you would know how to react ;) 4.) PC compatibility. -I played this game on a notebook with Intel Celeron (N2840 2.16 GHz) and 2GB ram. The game had some lag to it but I was still able to play it. So my notebook specs are pretty bad and I'm still able to run this game so yeah, as far being able to play this on low spec computers, the game wouuld still run okay. 5.) Challenge modes pack quite a challenge. -Even after you've finished the story mode, there are still some challange modes you could complete (like extra missions). So the game does not stop in the campaign and you could still relive those butt-kicking scenes over and over again.  So in the end is it worth it? Yes, and it is amazing. This game just set the standards of superhero games. In the Arkham series, this may be my favorite one (I have yet to play Arkha Knight but meh, I don't really expect much). I just hoped the campaign did not end so fast. So yes, I love this game as much as I love Batman. So yeah, buy it! *Now, to the Batcave!*
